DR. HOLLANDER PRAISES
CHARLES P. NEILL
Annapolis, Md., March t8.—That
Dr. Charles P. Neill, Commissioner
of Labor, who, by skillful arbitration
recently averted a strike on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in this
State, is worth more to Maryland
than a year's appropriation to higher education was the declaration of
Dr. Jacob H. Hollander of the Johns
Hopkins University before a joint
meeting of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and
Means Committee, where he appeared
in opposition to a bill giving the State
Board of Charities certain supervision of the various sums appropriated by the State for educational and
other institutions. Dr. Neill, who
was formerly a student of economics
at Johns Hopkins, was pointed out
by Dr. Hollander as a good practical example of the benefit of higher
education to the State.
What Dr. Hollander objected to
principally was that provision of the
bill that hereafter all State aid to
higher education be made on the
basis of so many scholarships to the
This, he contended, would
State.
give a distinct advantage to the rich.
Secretary Lloyd Wilkinson of the
Charities Board championed the bill.

"HOPKINS NIGHT" AT
SOUTHERN TEA ROOM
Tonight will be "Hopkins night"
at the -Southern Tea Room, the headquarters of the Just Government
League. Invitations to attend the
suffrage meeting to be held there
have been scattered broadcast among
the students at the Hopkins, especially among those at the Medical School.
The meeting is being arranged by
Dr. Florence R. Sabin, herself a
member of the faculty of the Medical School; Miss Marion Houghton,
Mrs. Butler and Mrs. Rainey. Dr.
Mary Sherwood, who is also a practicing physician, will be one of the
speakers.
On Saturday, March 26, Miss M.
L. Manning will be the drawing card
at the Southern Tea Room. Miss
Manning is an Australian girl, coming as a missionary to the disfranchised women of this country.
Miss Manning will become the
Just Government League's chief tadtician, organizer and campaigner.
She is now junior bursar at Bryn
Mawr College, but will resign that
position shortly to take up her work
for the League in Baltimore.—The
Sun.

DEBATE GOES TO 1910
Seniors Win After Close Struggle — Brown Wins Adams
Medal.
Considering the bad weather last
Thursday week, there was a very
satisfactory audience present in McCoy Hall on the occasion of the thirteenth annual interclass debate and
public speaking contest. The senior s,
taking the affirmative of the question,
"The granting of further subsidies to
American shipping would be an unwise policy," were represented by
Robert Edwin Miller, Norman Clyde
Marvel and Thomas Brooke Price,
with Carl Henry Levan alternate, and
Gilbert White Rosenthal adviser and
chairman. The negative was very
forcefully represented by Lingurn
Burkhead Bobbitt, chairman; James
Reaney Wolfe and Lindsay Rogers,
with Edwin Louis Frederick, alternate, and A. L. Starck, adviser.
Both teams are to be complimented on the thorough and painstaking
preparation which the debate showed,
and particularly was this to be remarked upon in regard to the firsthand information and opinions which
the debaters of both teams had gotten from such men of prominence as
Baron Kikuchi, who lectured here recently, and Bernard N. Baker, a trustee of this University, and greatly
interested in our national merchant
marine.
Under the conditions of the Adams
endowment a set of books will be
presented to each member of the winning team. The debate was judged
by Dr. Bernard C. Steiner, Albert C.
Ritchie, and Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, the exercises being presided over by Dr. J. C. French, of the department of English of the University.
The contest in public speaking preceded the debate, and Professor Ella
A. Knapp, Rev. Robert B. Zeigler
and Charles K. Edmunds, the judges,
awarded the Adams medal to William
Norman Brown for his selection,"The
Protection of American Citizens," by
Frye.
The committee of arrangements
consisted of Messrs. Otis Draper
(chairman), Harold B. Hering, D. S.
Elliott, R. F. D. Gable, and Aaron
Robinson. Music was furnished by
J. F. Wurzbacher's Orchestra.
The ushers were Messrs. George
Ross Veazey, T. S. Will, A. Vogeler,
C. H. Tilghman, E. B. Clary, E. D.
Martin, J. G. Murray, R. S. McCabe,
B. Tappan, E. 0. Hulburt, H. B. Waters, G. L. Schmeisser, W. 0. Weyforth, L. Wolman, E. Novak and J.
S. Dickinson.

THE NEWS-LETTER, March
HONOR SYSTEM
Baltimore, Md., 2nd March, 1910.
To the Faculty and Undergraduate
Students, Johns Hopkins University.
Gentlemen:
We beg to submit for your approval and ratification the following
Constitution to govern the practical
working of the Honor System at the
University:
Constitution.
Article I. Section 1. The Honor
System shall govern all examinations
(final, term, condition, and special)
except the spring and autumn examinations for admission, all written quizzes, and all written exercises
if the instructor require it.
Section 2. Each student upon entering the University shall sign the
following pledge before the Honor
Council. I hereby pledge my word
of honor to neither directly nor indirectly give or receive any help whatsoever during any examination, written quiz, or written exercise so required while I am an undergraduate
student at Johns Hopkins and I further pledge my word of honor to report
to the Chairman of my class Honor
Committee any one whomsoever I
shall know to have broken the first
clause in this pledge.
Section 3. If any student is unwilling to sign this pledge he will be
understood as preferring to take his
examinations and written quizzes and
doing his written exercises under
such safeguards as the Faculty may
deem necessary.
Section 4. Each student shall make
declaration
and sign the following
at the end of each examination or
written quiz paper, and on such written exercises as required by the instructor. I give my word of honor
that I have neither given nor received help , during this examination
(quiz) (in preparing this exercise.)
Article II. Section I. For the enforcement of the Honor System
there shall be an Honor Committee
in each class and an Honor Council.
Section 2. Each class Honor Committee shall consist of three men and
there shall be at least one fraternity
and one non-fraternity man on each
Committee.
Section 3. The members of the
Honor Committees shall he elected
by their own class at a meeting held
one week after the nominations are
made. There may be any number of
nominations and each member of the
class present shall write the names
of three of the nominees on paper,
but he must vote for at least one
fraternity and one non-fraternity
man. The fraternity and non-fraternity man receiving the greatest
number of votes shall be declared
elected and the third member of the
Committee shall be that candidate
receiving the highest number of votes,
regardless as to whether he he a fraternity or a non-fraternity man. The
Committees shall serve for one year,

or till such time as their successors
be elected. Vacancies in the Committees shall be filled by the class in
the same manner as tho regular elections.
Section 4. Each Honor Committee
shall elect from its own number a
chairman and the four chairmen shall
constitute the Honor Council, which
shall be presided over by the Senior
Class representative.
Section 5. Each member of the
Honor Committees shall sign the
following pledge: I hereby pledge
my word of honor to investigate and
decide faithfully and impartially,
without fear or favor, all cases that
may come before me for decision,
and I further give word of honor to
maintain strict secrecy regarding
all transactions and affairs of the
Honor Committees or the Honor
Council.
Article III. Section 1. A student
accused of breaking his honor pledge
shall be first tried by his class Honor
Committee, which in the case of the
two under classes shall be presided
over by the Senior Chairman. He
and the informant together with such
witnesses as the Committre shall see
fit to call shall appear. If there he
one vote of "Guilty" the Chairman
of the Committee shall make a written statement of the case which the
Committee shall all sign, and he
shall present it to the Honor Council. The Honor Council may re-open
the case and call any whom it wishes
before it. After the case has been
heard the members of the Honor
Council, except the representative
from the accused's class, shall vote
by written ballot until a unanimous decision is reached. If the
accused be found guilty the whole
Honor Council shall decide upon the
punishment to be recommended to
the Faculty, which may be suspension for such time as thought best,
dismissal from the University, or in
extreme cases public disgrace and
dismissal.
Section 2. In the case of the accused being a member of the Senior
Class he shall only be tried by his
own class Committee, which shall
come to a unanimous decision and
recommend the punishment to the
Faculty.
Section 3.
Special students shall
he regarded as members of that class
with which they enter the University unless they come credited with
college work when they shall be considered members of that class with
which they take most courses. The
Honor System shall not refer or govern in any way graduate students
students taking undergraduate courses, unless such a student desires that
it should.
Respectfully submitted,
Theodore S. Will.
For the Class of 1910

21, 1910.

THE NEWS-LETTER, March

6
A professor at Michigan says that
the West is thirty-six years ahead
of the East in oratory. Evidently he
never attended a Wednesday afternoon -Public Sleeping" course at
Hopkins. Anyway we wish he had
been more exact, for upon careful
study of all available statistics we
figure it that it is only thirty-four
years, three weeks, two hours, six
minutes and fourteen seconds, and
it is always unfair to compare with
a man using round numbers.
There was a jolly young colonel
Who took a poison intolonel:
First the stopper he licked,
Then the bucket he kicked,
And then went to regions in folonel.
The University of California already has a baseball squad on the
University
Kioto
diamond; the
(Japan) is thinking of sending a
team to this country for some intercollegiate games.; the team of the
University of Wisconsin which has
been on a tour in the Orient has returned—all in all it looks as if the
West were going right after the
"pennant."
At Dartmouth the students in Economics are taught not from text
books, but from the New York papers to which they have to subscribe.
Some of us down in Baltimore have
taken valuable lessons in this same
subject from Prof. Hindoo of The
Telegraph.
The French phonograph on the
second floor is eclipsed by a moving
picture machine used at Cornell's
Agricultural Department. The bill
for last week was "Nellie the Beautiful Milkmaid, or The Brindle
Cow's Revenge."
A student who has two unexcused
absences at Reserve is required to
take a special examination if he is
to get a credit. Here is evidently
something that our faculty have overlooked and we did not think they
had missed a single preventive for
making Hopkins as easy and pleasant as possible for us.
Dr. Henry Vandyke, professor of
English Literature at Princeton, has
recently been honored by election to
the Royal Literary Society of England. Ambassador Choate is the
only other American who has ever
been a member of this Society.

DR. HOLLANDER PRAISES
CHARLES P. NEILL
Annapolis, Md., March t8.—That
Dr. Charles P. Neill, Commissioner
of Labor, who, by skillful arbitration
recently averted a strike on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in this
State, is worth more to Maryland
than a year's appropriation to higher education was the declaration of
Dr. Jacob H. Hollander of the Johns
Hopkins University before a joint
meeting of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and
Means Committee, where he appeared
in opposition to a bill giving the State
Board of Charities certain supervision of the various sums appropriated by the State for educational and
other institutions. Dr. Neill, who
was formerly a student of economics
at Johns Hopkins, was pointed out
by Dr. Hollander as a good practical example of the benefit of higher
education to the State.
What Dr. Hollander objected to
principally was that provision of the
bill that hereafter all State aid to
higher education be made on the
basis of so many scholarships to the
This, he contended, would
State.
give a distinct advantage to the rich.
Secretary Lloyd Wilkinson of the
Charities Board championed the bill.

"HOPKINS NIGHT" AT
SOUTHERN TEA ROOM
Tonight will be "Hopkins night"
at the -Southern Tea Room, the headquarters of the Just Government
League. Invitations to attend the
suffrage meeting to be held there
have been scattered broadcast among
the students at the Hopkins, especially among those at the Medical School.
The meeting is being arranged by
Dr. Florence R. Sabin, herself a
member of the faculty of the Medical School; Miss Marion Houghton,
Mrs. Butler and Mrs. Rainey. Dr.
Mary Sherwood, who is also a practicing physician, will be one of the
speakers.
On Saturday, March 26, Miss M.
L. Manning will be the drawing card
at the Southern Tea Room. Miss
Manning is an Australian girl, coming as a missionary to the disfranchised women of this country.
Miss Manning will become the
Just Government League's chief tadtician, organizer and campaigner.
She is now junior bursar at Bryn
Mawr College, but will resign that
position shortly to take up her work
for the League in Baltimore.—The
Sun.

DEBATE GOES TO 1910
Seniors Win After Close Struggle — Brown Wins Adams
Medal.
Considering the bad weather last
Thursday week, there was a very
satisfactory audience present in McCoy Hall on the occasion of the thirteenth annual interclass debate and
public speaking contest. The senior s,
taking the affirmative of the question,
"The granting of further subsidies to
American shipping would be an unwise policy," were represented by
Robert Edwin Miller, Norman Clyde
Marvel and Thomas Brooke Price,
with Carl Henry Levan alternate, and
Gilbert White Rosenthal adviser and
chairman. The negative was very
forcefully represented by Lingurn
Burkhead Bobbitt, chairman; James
Reaney Wolfe and Lindsay Rogers,
with Edwin Louis Frederick, alternate, and A. L. Starck, adviser.
Both teams are to be complimented on the thorough and painstaking
preparation which the debate showed,
and particularly was this to be remarked upon in regard to the firsthand information and opinions which
the debaters of both teams had gotten from such men of prominence as
Baron Kikuchi, who lectured here recently, and Bernard N. Baker, a trustee of this University, and greatly
interested in our national merchant
marine.
Under the conditions of the Adams
endowment a set of books will be
presented to each member of the winning team. The debate was judged
by Dr. Bernard C. Steiner, Albert C.
Ritchie, and Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, the exercises being presided over by Dr. J. C. French, of the department of English of the University.
The contest in public speaking preceded the debate, and Professor Ella
A. Knapp, Rev. Robert B. Zeigler
and Charles K. Edmunds, the judges,
awarded the Adams medal to William
Norman Brown for his selection,"The
Protection of American Citizens," by
Frye.
The committee of arrangements
consisted of Messrs. Otis Draper
(chairman), Harold B. Hering, D. S.
Elliott, R. F. D. Gable, and Aaron
Robinson. Music was furnished by
J. F. Wurzbacher's Orchestra.
The ushers were Messrs. George
Ross Veazey, T. S. Will, A. Vogeler,
C. H. Tilghman, E. B. Clary, E. D.
Martin, J. G. Murray, R. S. McCabe,
B. Tappan, E. 0. Hulburt, H. B. Waters, G. L. Schmeisser, W. 0. Weyforth, L. Wolman, E. Novak and J.
S. Dickinson.

THE NEWS-LETTER, March
HONOR SYSTEM
Baltimore, Md., 2nd March, 1910.
To the Faculty and Undergraduate
Students, Johns Hopkins University.
Gentlemen:
We beg to submit for your approval and ratification the following
Constitution to govern the practical
working of the Honor System at the
University:
Constitution.
Article I. Section 1. The Honor
System shall govern all examinations
(final, term, condition, and special)
except the spring and autumn examinations for admission, all written quizzes, and all written exercises
if the instructor require it.
Section 2. Each student upon entering the University shall sign the
following pledge before the Honor
Council. I hereby pledge my word
of honor to neither directly nor indirectly give or receive any help whatsoever during any examination, written quiz, or written exercise so required while I am an undergraduate
student at Johns Hopkins and I further pledge my word of honor to report
to the Chairman of my class Honor
Committee any one whomsoever I
shall know to have broken the first
clause in this pledge.
Section 3. If any student is unwilling to sign this pledge he will be
understood as preferring to take his
examinations and written quizzes and
doing his written exercises under
such safeguards as the Faculty may
deem necessary.
Section 4. Each student shall make
declaration
and sign the following
at the end of each examination or
written quiz paper, and on such written exercises as required by the instructor. I give my word of honor
that I have neither given nor received help , during this examination
(quiz) (in preparing this exercise.)
Article II. Section I. For the enforcement of the Honor System
there shall be an Honor Committee
in each class and an Honor Council.
Section 2. Each class Honor Committee shall consist of three men and
there shall be at least one fraternity
and one non-fraternity man on each
Committee.
Section 3. The members of the
Honor Committees shall he elected
by their own class at a meeting held
one week after the nominations are
made. There may be any number of
nominations and each member of the
class present shall write the names
of three of the nominees on paper,
but he must vote for at least one
fraternity and one non-fraternity
man. The fraternity and non-fraternity man receiving the greatest
number of votes shall be declared
elected and the third member of the
Committee shall be that candidate
receiving the highest number of votes,
regardless as to whether he he a fraternity or a non-fraternity man. The
Committees shall serve for one year,

or till such time as their successors
be elected. Vacancies in the Committees shall be filled by the class in
the same manner as tho regular elections.
Section 4. Each Honor Committee
shall elect from its own number a
chairman and the four chairmen shall
constitute the Honor Council, which
shall be presided over by the Senior
Class representative.
Section 5. Each member of the
Honor Committees shall sign the
following pledge: I hereby pledge
my word of honor to investigate and
decide faithfully and impartially,
without fear or favor, all cases that
may come before me for decision,
and I further give word of honor to
maintain strict secrecy regarding
all transactions and affairs of the
Honor Committees or the Honor
Council.
Article III. Section 1. A student
accused of breaking his honor pledge
shall be first tried by his class Honor
Committee, which in the case of the
two under classes shall be presided
over by the Senior Chairman. He
and the informant together with such
witnesses as the Committre shall see
fit to call shall appear. If there he
one vote of "Guilty" the Chairman
of the Committee shall make a written statement of the case which the
Committee shall all sign, and he
shall present it to the Honor Council. The Honor Council may re-open
the case and call any whom it wishes
before it. After the case has been
heard the members of the Honor
Council, except the representative
from the accused's class, shall vote
by written ballot until a unanimous decision is reached. If the
accused be found guilty the whole
Honor Council shall decide upon the
punishment to be recommended to
the Faculty, which may be suspension for such time as thought best,
dismissal from the University, or in
extreme cases public disgrace and
dismissal.
Section 2. In the case of the accused being a member of the Senior
Class he shall only be tried by his
own class Committee, which shall
come to a unanimous decision and
recommend the punishment to the
Faculty.
Section 3.
Special students shall
he regarded as members of that class
with which they enter the University unless they come credited with
college work when they shall be considered members of that class with
which they take most courses. The
Honor System shall not refer or govern in any way graduate students
students taking undergraduate courses, unless such a student desires that
it should.
Respectfully submitted,
Theodore S. Will.
For the Class of 1910

21, 1910.

THE NEWS-LETTER, March

6
A professor at Michigan says that
the West is thirty-six years ahead
of the East in oratory. Evidently he
never attended a Wednesday afternoon -Public Sleeping" course at
Hopkins. Anyway we wish he had
been more exact, for upon careful
study of all available statistics we
figure it that it is only thirty-four
years, three weeks, two hours, six
minutes and fourteen seconds, and
it is always unfair to compare with
a man using round numbers.
There was a jolly young colonel
Who took a poison intolonel:
First the stopper he licked,
Then the bucket he kicked,
And then went to regions in folonel.
The University of California already has a baseball squad on the
University
Kioto
diamond; the
(Japan) is thinking of sending a
team to this country for some intercollegiate games.; the team of the
University of Wisconsin which has
been on a tour in the Orient has returned—all in all it looks as if the
West were going right after the
"pennant."
At Dartmouth the students in Economics are taught not from text
books, but from the New York papers to which they have to subscribe.
Some of us down in Baltimore have
taken valuable lessons in this same
subject from Prof. Hindoo of The
Telegraph.
The French phonograph on the
second floor is eclipsed by a moving
picture machine used at Cornell's
Agricultural Department. The bill
for last week was "Nellie the Beautiful Milkmaid, or The Brindle
Cow's Revenge."
A student who has two unexcused
absences at Reserve is required to
take a special examination if he is
to get a credit. Here is evidently
something that our faculty have overlooked and we did not think they
had missed a single preventive for
making Hopkins as easy and pleasant as possible for us.
Dr. Henry Vandyke, professor of
English Literature at Princeton, has
recently been honored by election to
the Royal Literary Society of England. Ambassador Choate is the
only other American who has ever
been a member of this Society.
